title: 106_hr5469
content: The Act titled "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2000" allows for judicial review of binational panel decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act. The "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2000" allows for judicial review of binational panel decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act within 30 days after publication in the Federal Register. If a party alleges gross misconduct, bias, serious conflict of interest, departure from procedural rules, or exceeding of powers by a panel, they can seek review in the Court of International Trade. The "Integrity of the United States Courts Act of 2000" allows for judicial review of binational panel decisions under the North American Free Trade Agreement Implementation Act within 30 days after publication in the Federal Register. If a party alleges serious departure from procedural rules or exceeding of powers by a panel, they can file an appeal with the United States Court of International Trade for review. The Court of International Trade reviews binational panel decisions under the Tariff Act of 1930. If actions described in the appeal are established, the original panel decision is vacated. Decisions of the Court are binding on the parties involved. The Court of International Trade has exclusive jurisdiction over appeals related to binational panel decisions under the Tariff Act of 1930. Decisions made by the Court are binding on the parties involved in matters before the panel. The Court of International Trade has exclusive jurisdiction over appeals related to binational panel decisions under the Tariff Act of 1930, and determinations on international trade are not subject to review by an extraordinary challenge committee. This section applies to all goods from NAFTA countries subject to antidumping or countervailing duty determinations in the United States. The Court of International Trade has exclusive jurisdiction over appeals related to binational panel decisions under the Tariff Act of 1930. This section applies to all goods from NAFTA countries subject to antidumping or countervailing duty determinations in the United States. Section 516A of the Tariff Act of 1930 is amended to include a final determination of a binational panel convened under NAFTA. This amendment also clarifies the application of certain determinations in subsections (a)(5) and (g)(3)(A). The amendment clarifies the application of certain determinations in subsection (g)(3)(A) of the Tariff Act of 1930 by adding a new provision for review requested under the NAFTA Implementation Act. The amendments made by this Act will apply to final determinations of binational panels under NAFTA article 1904 published in the Federal Register after the enactment date of this Act.
